Notes: needs knowledge to avoid competition (semi-arid!); no fertilization; pigeon pea still sold

Legume name: Climbing beans (Phaseolus vulgaris), local types available in W Ethiopia, harvested several (4-5) years before reseeding)

Notes: less land requirements in intercropping; less labour required than eg green grams; not difficult but susceptible to disease/pest; market site-dependent: in Kenya would not be grown without market (or less), but in DRC/Rwanda... also grown w/o market just for food
more than groundnut, eg shelling, also digging them up; uses fertilizer (P) and inoculum; knowledge intensive (ridges and soil adding at flowering in Ethiopia but not in Uganda)

Legume name: Soybean/dual purpose grain plus fodder (Glycine max L.)

Notes: difficult to get seed, usually monocropped, sometimes intercropped

Legume name: Chickpea (Cicer arietinum L.) – desi type (for food)- following the main crop
Notes: grows on residual moisture. Seeds are saved

Legume name: Chickpea (Cicer arietinum L.) – kabuli type (for export)-main crop

Notes: marketing challenging due to variability in cookability
sown as green manure after cereals.

Legume name: Field Pea (Pisum sativum L), adapted to high rainfall environment
Field pea (Pisum absynicum var. sativum)-adapted to low rainfall environment

Notes: not all farmers know it, but management not difficult only seeds are small and more difficult to plant than mucuna; no fertilizer and chemicals; fodder legume not grown if there is no milk market

labour for chopping (green manure); many people don't know it, but management is easy; mucuna adoption commonly constrained by land availability; investment in soil quality only if cash crop can benefit from it
land requirements low if as fence and spot; cutting, chopping, feeding takes labour; some initial input and labour (nursery) but after establishment hardly any; indirect market for milk
Labour needed for pruning and propagation
more labour  and input needed than calliandra bc re-planting needed. Self propogates
